body:
> The registration results using the TF or PyTorch model are the same, however I observed that more computational resources were required for registration when using a PyTorch model, on CPUs. This can be quite limiting for registration of large 3D images. To illustrate this point, @EvanBeal and I have created a reproducible example. 1. Download `cascaded-registration-example.zip` and `cascaded_models_pytorch.zip` from [this link](https://github.com/ivadomed/multimodal-registration/releases/tag/r20220512). 2. Extract `cascaded-registration-example.zip`. 3. Extract `cascaded_models_pytorch.zip` and copy the model files into the `model/` folder from step 2. 4. Run the following commands: ```bash cd cascaded-registration-example python -m venv venv source venv/bin/activate pip install -r requirements.txt python cascaded-registration.py ``` At time of writing, this will result in the following logs:
pip install -r requirements.txt ```console (venv) joshua@tadpole:~/Desktop/cascaded-registration-example$ pip install -r requirements.txt Looking in indexes: https://pypi.org/simple, https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cpu Collecting torch Using cached https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cpu/torch-1.11.0%2Bcpu-cp37-cp37m-linux_x86_64.whl (169.1 MB) Collecting nilearn Using cached nilearn-0.9.1-py3-none-any.whl (9.6 MB) Collecting voxelmorph@ git+https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph@579a995492bddfe9ce38161e58cf260fc155c4fd Cloning https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph python cascaded-registration.py ```console (venv) joshua@tadpole:~/Desktop/cascaded-registration-example$ python cascaded-registration.py ### Loading data files... ### Input shape for fixed image: (192, 256, 320) ### Input shape for moving image: (192, 256, 320) ### Padding data files... ### Creating data tensors... ### Input shape for fixed tensor: torch.Size([1, 1, 192, 256, 320]) ### Input shape for moving tensor: torch.Size([1, 1, 192, 256, 320]) ### Creating VxmDense models with arguments: {'inshape': [192, 256, 320], 'int_steps': 5, 'int_downsize': 2, 'unet_half_res': True, 'nb_unet_features': ([256, 256, 256, 256], [256, 256, 256, 256, 256, 256])} ### Loading first VxmDense model... /home/joshua/Desktop/cascaded-registration-example/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/torch/functional.py:568: UserWarning: torch.meshgrid: in an upcoming release, it will be required to pass the indexing argument. Running [`dmesg`](https://stackoverflow.com/a/65352421) afterwards shows: ``` [13431.495233] Out of memory: Killed process 21402 (python) total-vm:18226108kB, anon-rss:11113872kB, file-rss:0kB, shmem-rss:0kB, UID:1000 pgtables:22864kB oom_score_adj:0 [13432.031921] oom_reaper: reaped process 21402 (python), now anon-rss:0kB, file-rss:0kB, shmem-rss:0kB ```

issue.title: Integrate EvanBeal's contrast agnostic registration model into SCT's registration scripts

repository.name: spinalcordtoolbox
repository.description: Comprehensive and open-source library of analysis tools for MRI of the spinal cord.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
This issue is for planning the integration of @EvanBeal's [contrast agnostic registration model project](https://github.com/ivadomed/multimodal-registration) into SCT's registration scripts.

### Proposed changes (copied from 2022-04-05 meeting minutes)

- Include preprocessing steps
- Load the models weights and build the architecture (using [VoxelMorph](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph) functions)
- Use the models to produce the warping field
- Transform the warping field so it can be used with sct_apply_transfo
- Call this function from the [register function](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/master/spinalcordtoolbox/scripts/sct_register_to_template.py#L1189) of `sct_register_to_template` 
    - And/or `sct_register_multimodal`? (TODO: Needs clarification)

### Remaining work

- [ ] Investigate if model can be converted to ONNX, or if we need to depend on VoxelMorph directly
   - NB: If it can't be converted, then SCT will have to depend on Tensorflow once more, which conflicts with the vision for #3735.

body:
To debug this issue, I started out by switching to a smaller versions of the input images. That way, I could run inference using the [PyTorch Profiler](https://pytorch.org/tutorials/recipes/recipes/profiler_recipe.html) without the process being killed.
Generating the smaller input images ```bash cd cascaded-registration-example/data # Cropping around the spinal cord (T1w) sct_deepseg_sc -i T1w.nii.gz -c t1 -centerline cnn sct_create_mask -i T1w.nii.gz -p centerline,T1w_seg.nii.gz -size 35mm -f cylinder -o mask_T1w.nii.gz sct_crop_image -i T1w.nii.gz -m mask_T1w.nii.gz # Cropping around the spinal cord (T2w) sct_deepseg_sc -i T2w.nii.gz -c t2 -centerline cnn sct_create_mask -i T2w.nii.gz -p centerline,T2w_seg.nii.gz -size 35mm -f cylinder -o mask_T2w.nii.gz sct_crop_image -i T2w.nii.gz -m mask_T2w.nii.gz ```
Profiling code ```python print("\n### Predicting using first VxmDense model...") from torch.profiler import profile, record_function, ProfilerActivity with profile(activities=[ProfilerActivity.CPU], record_shapes=True, profile_memory=True) as prof: with record_function("model_inference"): try: moved, warp_tensor = pt_first_model(input_moving, input_fixed, registration=True) warp_data_first = warp_tensor[0].permute(1, 2, 3, 0).detach().numpy() except Exception as e: print(f"Caught exception:\n{e}") print("\n### Displaying model profiling...") print(prof.key_averages(group_by_input_shape=True).table(sort_by="self_cpu_memory_usage", row_limit=10)) ```
I then varied the size of the input images using padding to see how the memory usage for the `VXMDense` model changes.
torch.Size([1, 1, 32, 80, 160]) ```bash ### Loading data files... ### Input shape for fixed image: (42, 95, 172) ### Input shape for moving image: (39, 101, 169) ### Padding data files... (scale=1.0) ### Creating data tensors... ### Input shape for fixed tensor: torch.Size([1, 1, 32, 80, 160]) ### Input shape for moving tensor: torch.Size([1, 1, 32, 80, 160]) ### Creating VxmDense models with arguments: {'inshape': [32, 80, 160], 'int_steps': 5, 'int_downsize': 2, 'unet_half_res': True, 'nb_unet_features': ([256, 256, 256, 256], [256, 256, 256, 256, 256, 256])} ### Loading first VxmDense model... C:\Users\Joshua\repos\spinalcordtoolbox\venv_sct\lib\site-packages\torch\functional.py:568: UserWarning: torch.meshgrid: in an upcoming release, it will be required to pass the indexing argument. (Triggered internally at C:\actions-runner\_work\pytorch\pytorch\builder\windows\pytorch\aten\src\ATen\native\TensorShape.cpp:2228.) return _VF.meshgrid(tensors, **kwargs) # type: ignore[attr-defined] ### Predicting using first VxmDense model... ### Displaying model profiling... --------------------------------- ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------ -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name Self CPU % Self CPU CPU total % CPU total CPU time avg CPU Mem Self CPU Mem # ((Going any larger started to run into memory issues, as I only have 16GB of RAM on my computer.))

Using `group_by_stack_n`, we can see that the most expensive `empty` calls are happening in the `ConvBlock` module within the `Unet` forward pass:

```bash
                                                                                                                                                   lib\site-packages\voxelmorph\torch\networks.py(244): forward
                                                                                                                                                   nn.Module: SpatialTransformer
                                                                                                                                                   lib\site-packages\voxelmorph\torch\layers.py(30): forward

                        aten::mul         0.01%      10.450ms         0.01%      10.559ms       3.520ms      54.14 Mb      54.14 Mb             3  nn.Module: VxmDense
                                                                                                                                                   lib\site-packages\voxelmorph\torch\networks.py(244): forward
                                                                                                                                                   nn.Module: SpatialTransformer
                                                                                                                                                   lib\site-packages\voxelmorph\torch\layers.py(30): forward

---------------------------------  ------------  ------------  ------------  ------------  ------------  ------------  ------------  ------------  ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Self CPU time total: 71.878s
```

</details>

At this point, I'm wondering if this is just inherent to Pytorch, given that we're performing [large convolutions on CPU](https://discuss.pytorch.org/t/pytorch-high-memory-demand/2798/2).

> This is specific to CPU  the CPU convolution code is not very optimized (for memory usage) and uses a lot of memory. The CUDA convolution implementation (via cuDNN) is much faster and uses less memory.

issue.title: `algo=dl` abruptly stops with no error message when used on images that are too large

labels.name: bug
labels.description: category: fixes an error in the code

repository.name: spinalcordtoolbox
repository.description: Comprehensive and open-source library of analysis tools for MRI of the spinal cord.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
As discovered in https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/pull/3865#issuecomment-1232161658, when the following command is run:

```
sct_register_multimodal -i _VISTA_Lspine_SENSE_20210922113031_2001.nii -d _VISTA_Tspine_SENSE_20210922113031_1901.nii -param step=1,type=im,algo=dl
```

The output of `sct_register_multimodal` abruptly stops when trying to predict using the second VxmDense model:

```
Load data to register...

 Creating data tensors...

 Input shape for fixed tensor: torch.Size([1, 1, 64, 304, 304])

 Input shape for moving tensor: torch.Size([1, 1, 64, 304, 304])

 Creating VxmDense models with arguments:

{'inshape': [64, 304, 304], 'int_steps': 5, 'int_downsize': 2, 'unet_half_res': True, 'nb_unet_features': ([256, 256, 256, 256], [256, 256, 256, 256, 256, 256])}

 Loading first VxmDense model...

 Loading second VxmDense model...

 Predicting using first VxmDense model...
```

There is no indication of what went wrong, so some investigation is needed.

> **NB:** This dataset is internal/private, and can be found on `duke` in `projects/template_dog_virginiatech`
